Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Multi-locus molecular phylogenetics of the genus Buddleja and insights into inflorescence evolution and historical biogeography
Award.AbstractNarration:
The genus Buddleja, commonly called the butterfly-bushes, is a group of flowering plants that includes approximately 110 species of shrubs and trees. They exhibit great diversity in the architecture of inflorescences, the structures in which groups of flowers are arranged, which has been hypothesized to be adaptations to different habitats and pollinators. Also, the group has a wide distribution, including areas of Africa, Asia, North America, and South America. Hypotheses concerning the geographic origin and dispersal history of the group and its relationship to past geologic and climatic events have been proposed but remain untested. The PIs will conduct a molecular phylogenetic study of the genus, using DNA sequences from multiple loci to infer evolutionary relationships among species. A novel high-throughput method of gathering genetic data will be developed. The inferred phylogenetic tree will be used in further analyses to test hypotheses about inflorescence architecture evolution and biogeographic history.

Reproductive architecture, including inflorescence form, is an important component of the success and diversification of flowering plants, and this project will contribute to elucidating patterns in its evolution and adaptive significance. The study of biogeographic history is important for understanding the formation of modern floras and current distributional patterns. Buddleja includes many species of conservation, ethnobotanical, and horticultural interest. Understanding species relationships will help guide future research in this group.

POR.DRECONTENT:
John Chau has completed his dissertation research on "Systematics of Buddleja (Scrophulariaceae): phylogenetic relationships, historical biogeography, and phylogenomics" supported by the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant. As a plant systematist, Chau is interested in plant diversity and the processes and patterns in how it originates. Buddleja is a genus with more than a hundred species, with a distribution spanning four continents and a rich diversity of flower and inflorescence forms. Chau's research focused on elucidating the relationships among species in the group, and using knowledge of the phylogeny, or family tree, to explore other questions about its evolutionary history, including how it attained such a large geographic range. Case studies on diverse groups like Buddleja can illuminate general patterns in how life on Earth evolved.

Modern studies on evolutionary relationships rely on comparing molecular data, particularly DNA sequences. In order to obtain DNA sequences, fresh or properly preserved tissue from a species is required, which is often not available for rare species from regions outside the U.S. During his funding period, Chau was able to travel to several regions whose flora includes Buddleja species, including South Africa, China, Bolivia, Costa Rica, and the southwest U.S. The specimens he collected were used in his molecular work and will be preserved in herbaria, museum collections of plant specimens that serve as permanent records of the flora at a particular time and place.

The results of Chau's work revealed the broad patterns in the relationships in Buddleja. Species from the same region, like the Americas, Asia, or Madagascar, form groups of closely related species, which conflicts with previous classifications that grouped species by morphology. Chau published his results in the peer-reviewed Botanical Journal of the Linnean Society and revised the classification to reflect evolutionary relationships. This phylogeny will serve as a framework for future studies on evolution in the group.

Using the phylogeny, Chau also studied how geographic distribution in the group has changed through time. He found that Buddleja originated in southern Africa. From Africa, the group spread in separate events to the Americas, Asia, and Madagascar. These movements are inferred to have occurred about 10 million years ago, when a warmer climate may have allowed the plants to grow at higher latitudes in regions that connected the continents. Upon reaching the mountainous, complex environment of the American cordilleras, the group exploded into many new species, producing the diversity observed today. Understanding how plants evolved and moved across the globe can help researchers explain current patterns of biodiversity and predict how future climatic and geologic changes will affect biodiversity in the future.

Chau has shared the results of his research with professional colleagues through presentations at university, national, and international conferences. He has also shared his work with general audiences at public events at museums, writings in museum newletters, and blog posts. During the course of his project, Chau has mentored five undergraduates on the theory and practice of scientific research. Several undergraduates have gone on to present their own research at university and national conferences and to prepare manuscripts for publication in peer-reviewed journals.
